raw_text:
Buyers snap up Jet Airways' shares
 
 Investors have snapped up shares in Jet Airways, India's biggest airline, following the launch of its much anticipated initial public offer (IPO).
 
 The IPO for 17.3 million shares was fully sold within 10 minutes of opening, on Friday. Analysts expect Jet to raise at least 16.4bn rupees ($375m; £198m) from the offering. Interest in Jet's IPO has been fuelled by hopes for robust growth in India's air travel market.
 
 The share offer, representing about 20% of Jet's equity, was oversubscribed, news agency Reuters reported. Jet, which was founded by London-based travel agent Naresh Goyal, plans to use the cash to buy new planes and cut its debt. The company has grown rapidly since it launched operations in 1993, overtaking state-owned flag carrier Indian Airlines. However, it faces stiff competition from rivals and low-cost carriers. Jet's IPO is the first in a series of expected share offers from Indian companies this year, as they move to raise funds to help them do business in a rapidly-growing economy.
llama3.2:1b: Buyers snap up Jet Airways shares following its initial public offer (IPO) which was fully sold within 10 minutes of opening on Friday. The IPO raised at least 16.4 billion rupees ($375 million; £198 million), while analysts expect Jet to raise more from the offering.
llama3.2:3b: Buyers snapped up 17.3 million shares of Jet Airways' in an initial public offer (IPO) that was fully subscribed within 10 minutes. Analysts expect the offering to raise at least 16.4 billion rupees ($375m; £198m). The company plans to use the funds to purchase new planes and reduce debt, following rapid growth since its launch in 1993.
gemma2:2b: Jet Airways' IPO was fully subscribed within 10 minutes of opening, raising at least $375 million. Investors are optimistic about the airline's growth prospects and are interested in its robust debt reduction plans. The offer is expected to help Jet Airways purchase new planes and reduce its financial obligations. This IPO marks one of several planned share offerings from Indian companies seeking funding for business expansion in a rapidly growing economy.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Jet Airways has been getting lots of investors' money lately. They bought 17 million shares at once, which took only about 10 minutes. The company plans to use the money to buy more planes and pay off debts. It's like when you want to buy a big toy from a store but don't have enough money. Jet wants to do that for its own business too. They're excited about getting those new shares.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Jet Airways shares are snapped up by investors following its $375 million initial public offering (IPO) on Friday, quickly reaching full subscription within 10 minutes. The company plans to use the proceeds for new plane purchases and debt reduction, aiming for robust growth in India's air travel market amid competition from rivals and low-cost carriers.

The IPO represents about 20% of Jet's equity and was oversubscribed. Established by Naresh Goyal as a London-based travel agent, Jet launched in 1993 and has grown to become India's biggest airline, overtaking state-owned flag carrier Indian Airlines. Despite rapid growth, Jet faces competition from rivals and low-cost carriers. This IPO is part of planned share offerings from Indian companies aimed at raising funds for their business in a growing economy.

Jet plans to use the cash to buy new planes and cut its debt, having grown rapidly since it launched operations in 1993. However, it faces stiff competition from Indian airlines."
smollm:1.7b:

1. Buyers snapped up shares in Jet Airways' IPO
2. Investors have snapped up shares in Jet Airways, India's biggest airline

4. Analysts expect Jet to raise at least 16.4bn rupees ($375m; £198m) from the offering

6. The share offer, representing about 20% of Jet's equity, was oversubscribed
7. Jet plans to use the cash to buy new planes and cut its debt
8. The company faces stiff competition from rivals and low-cost carriers
9. Jet's IPO is the first in a series of expected share offers from Indian companies this year
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Jet Airways' initial public offer (IPO). Let me read through it carefully.

The main points are: buyers snapped up Jet shares, the IPO was for 17.3 million shares sold quickly in 10 minutes on Friday, and the company raised at least 16.4 billion rupees. That's a significant amount. Investors were hopeful about India's growing air travel market, so they wanted to see Jet take off.

The share offer was oversubscribed, which means there were more offers than available shares. This could make it harder for companies with fewer shares to get in on the deal. But since the company is expanding and already surpassed Indian Airlines, it has some support from them.

Additionally, the IPO is part of a series that Indian companies are doing this year to help them grow in an economy that's booming. So, Jet's IPO isn't just about buying new planes; it's also about getting more money to go after its expansion and competition issues.

I think I should mention how many shares were sold, the amount raised, and why investors are interested in Jet despite any oversubscription. Also, include their plans to buy new planes and reduce debt, which shows they're looking for a stable business environment.

So putting it all together: Investors snapped up Jet's 17 million shares quickly, raising significant funds, with hopes of solidifying their presence in India's air travel market despite potential oversubscription. Their strategy is clear—buy more planes, reduce debt, and support existing strong competitors.
</think>

Buyers snapped up Jet Airways' 17.3 million shares on Friday, marking the initial public offer (IPO). The company raised at least 16.4 billion rupees ($375m; £198m) from the offering, driven by optimism about India's growing air travel market. Despite potential oversubscription, investors are drawn to Jet's plans to invest in new planes and reduce debt, as well as its position to compete with established competitors like Indian Airlines.
tinyllama:1.1b: Investors snapped up shares in Jet Airways following the launch of its much anticipated initial public offering (IPO), with shares selling for 17.3 million units within 10 minutes of opening, on Friday. The IPO was widely expected to generate at least £198m ($375m) from a stock offering, according to analysts. While Jet's share offer is the first in a series of expected IPOs this year, it faces stiff competition and low-cost carriers. The company has grown rapidly since its foundation in 1993 by London-based travel agent Naresh Goyal.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Investors have snapped up shares in Jet Airways, India's biggest airline, following the launch of its much anticipated initial public offer (IPO). The IPO for 17.3 million shares was fully sold within 10 minutes of opening, on Friday. Analysts expect Jet to raise at least 16.4 billion rupees ($375 million; £198 million) from the offering. The share offer has been oversubscribed, with investors snapping up shares at a rate of about 20% of its equity. Jet plans to use the cash to buy new planes and cut its debt, which it had amassed in response to financial losses in the past. With its rapid growth, Jet Airways now competes with state-owned flag carrier Indian Airlines, but faces stiff competition from low-cost carriers.

Despite competition from other airlines, it has grown rapidly since its founding in 2003. This IPO comes amidst a wave of expected share offers by Indian companies this year.

However, the airline faces stiff competition from other airlines in India's rapidly growing aviation industry.
